sub_subject.name: Civics, Government & Law
sub_subject.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Civics, Government & Law (History & Social Studies)

objectives.objective_text: Identify that every person is made by God.
Name 'Rights' as good things God gives us.
Identify what is 'Fair' and 'Unfair'.
Name a judge as someone who decides what is right.
Identify the Golden Rule in laws.
Identify police officers and leaders as helpers.
Name God as the one who gives leaders power.
Identify the Amendments (changes/additions).
Identify polite words.
Name listening as important.
Identify voting as making a choice.
Name Election Day.
Identify the requirements to vote.
Identify a King or Queen.
Name a Dictator as a bossy leader.
Identify countries that are not free today.
Identify voting.
Name the USA as a Republic.
Identify the danger of the 'mob'.
Identify the Constitution as a rule book.
Name the Judges who read the rule book.
Identify a Judge and a Jury.
Name a Courtroom as a place for truth.
Identify the Supreme Court as the highest court.
Identify that the President can say 'No' (Veto).
Name the Supreme Court as the referee.
Identify Impeachment (firing a leader).
Identify the Constitution as the supreme rule book.
Name 'We the People'.
Identify my State and my Country.
Name the Governor and the President.
Identify powers shared (like taxes).
Identify three groups who run the country.
Name the President (Leader), Congress (Law-makers), Judges.
Identify who makes the laws.
Identify that we are free to go to church.
Name 'Freedom of Speech'.
Identify 'Due Process' (fair rules).
Recall that we should treat everyone kindly.
Observe that rules protect people.
Recall that God loves justice.
Observe that rules should be the same for everyone.
Recall that we should obey the law.
Observe that bad guys get punished.
Recall that we can be friends even if we disagree.
Observe people talking calmly.
Recall that we choose our leaders.
Observe an 'I Voted' sticker.
Recall that some people are not free.
Observe that we are lucky to be free.
Recall that we choose people to speak for us.
Observe that the people are the boss.
Recall that rules mean what they say.
Observe that we can't change rules in the middle of a game.
Recall that we promise to tell the truth.
Observe a gavel.
Recall that they watch each other.
Observe that it is hard to change the rules.
Recall that the President has to follow the rules too.
Observe the flag as a symbol of our country.
Recall that states have their own rules too.
Observe different license plates.
Recall that sharing power is safer.
Observe the three different buildings in DC.
Recall that the police must follow rules too.
Observe that we can say what we think.
Summarize why human life is special (Image of God).
Explain that rights come from God, not the government.
Explain the concept of 'Unalienable Rights'.
Defend the dignity of the unborn and vulnerable.
Summarize 'Lady Justice' (Blindfold, Scales, Sword).
Explain why favorites are bad in a court.
Defend the concept of impartiality in judgment (Leviticus 19:15).
Summarize what Romans 13 says (punish evil, praise good).
Explain why we need a government (because of sin).
Explain the concept of 'Ordered Liberty'.
Defend the legitimacy of capital punishment in biblical law.
Summarize how to disagree without being mean.
Explain what 'Free Speech' means.
Explain the 'Straw Man' fallacy.
Defend the Christian duty to be 'salt and light' in politics.
Summarize how we elect a President (Electoral College intro).
Explain why every vote counts.
Explain the role of the media in elections.
Defend the responsibility of the informed voter.
Summarize what a Monarchy is.
Explain what a Dictatorship is (one person has all power).
Explain the concept of a 'Police State'.
Defend the right of resistance to tyranny.
Summarize the difference between Direct Democracy (everyone votes on everything) and Representative Democracy.
Explain the Pledge of Allegiance ('to the Republic').
Explain the Parliamentary system vs. Presidential system.
Defend the Constitutional Republic as the best protection for liberty.
Summarize why we need judges to explain the laws.
Explain that the Constitution is hard to change.
Explain 'Judicial Activism' vs. 'Judicial Restraint'.
Defend a specific method of interpretation.
Summarize what a Jury does (decides guilty or innocent).
Explain the difference between a Lawyer and a Judge.
Explain the selection process for federal judges.
Defend the right to a trial by peers.
Summarize how a Bill becomes a Law.
Explain what a Veto is.
Explain how gridlock protects liberty.
Defend the Senate filibuster (protection of minority).
Summarize the Preamble.
Explain 'Popular Sovereignty' (people have the power).
Explain the process of ratification.
Defend the stability provided by a written constitution.
Summarize the difference between Federal (Big) and State (Small) government.
Explain the 10th Amendment (powers kept by states).
Explain the benefits of laboratories of democracy (states trying new things).
Defend the principle of Subsidiarity (solving problems locally).
Summarize the job of each branch (Legislative, Executive, Judicial).
Explain why we don't let one person do everything.
Explain the danger of consolidation of power.
Defend the inefficiency of the system as a feature, not a bug.
Summarize the First Amendment (Speech, Religion, Press, Assembly, Petition).
Explain the Right to Bear Arms (2nd).
Explain the 'Establishment Clause' vs. 'Free Exercise Clause'.
Defend the view of 'Negative Rights' (freedom *from* government) vs. 'Positive Rights'.
Compare a Primary election with a General election.
Compare a right (Freedom) with a privilege (Driving).
Apply the idea of dignity to how we treat enemies.
Analyze the Declaration of Independence ('Endowed by their Creator').
Interpret the connection between God's law and human law.
Connect the sanctity of life to political issues.
Compare Biblical justice (restitution) with revenge.
Analyze the concept of 'Rule of Law' vs. 'Rule of Man'.
Interpret Micah 6:8 (Do Justice).
Compare a good leader (servant) with a bad leader (bully).
Apply respect to leaders even if we disagree.
Analyze the sword of the state (authority to punish).
Interpret the limit of authority (when to disobey).
Connect government to the Noahic Covenant (Genesis 9).
Explain the difference between Equality (opportunity) and Equity (outcome - *note: distinct from modern political usage*).
Compare a debate with a fight.
Apply respect to someone with a different opinion.
Analyze the concept of the 'Public Square'.
Interpret the First Amendment rights to assemble and petition.
Connect social media to the decline of civil discourse.
Analyze the Electoral College (Why we have it).
Interpret a political map (Red/Blue states).
Connect the census to representation.
Compare a President with a King.
Analyze the characteristics of Totalitarianism.
Interpret the lack of rights in Communist and Fascist states.
Connect the Divine Right of Kings to history.
Compare Athens (Democracy) with Rome (Republic).
Analyze the phrase 'Tyranny of the Majority'.
Interpret the protections for the minority in a Republic.
Connect the Founding Fathers' fear of democracy to the Constitution.
Compare reading the text with guessing the intent.
Apply the idea of fairness.
Analyze the debate: Originalism vs. Living Constitution.
Interpret the role of the Supreme Court in shaping society.
Connect Marbury v. Madison to Judicial Review.
Compare a trial court with an appeals court.
Analyze the difference between Civil Law (disputes) and Criminal Law (crimes).
Interpret 'Beyond a Reasonable Doubt'.
Connect jurisdiction to geography and topic.
Compare the power of the President with the power of Congress.
Analyze the Veto Override process.
Interpret Judicial Review (declaring laws unconstitutional).
Connect Senate confirmation to Presidential appointments.
Compare a Monarchy (King rules) with a Republic (Law rules).
Analyze the structure of the Articles.
Interpret the 'Supremacy Clause'.
Connect the failure of the Articles of Confederation to the Constitution.
Compare a Driver's License (State) with a Passport (Federal).
Analyze the concept of 'Dual Sovereignty'.
Interpret the 'Enumerated Powers' of Congress.
Connect the Civil War to the changing view of Federalism.
Compare a football team (different roles) to the government.
Analyze the specific powers granted to Congress (Article I).
Interpret the powers of the Presidency (Article II).
Connect human depravity (sin) to the need for separation.
Compare a country with rights to a country without them.
Analyze the protection against unreasonable search and seizure (4th).
Interpret 'Cruel and Unusual Punishment' (8th).
Connect the Anti-Federalists to the demand for a Bill of Rights.
Evaluate secular theories of rights (Social Contract vs. Divine Gift).
Evaluate the tension between Acts 5:29 (Obey God) and Romans 13.
Connect the Law of Moses to modern justice (evidence, witnesses).
Evaluate the limits of free speech (libel, incitement).
Evaluate the two-party system.
Evaluate the efficiency vs. liberty trade-off.
Evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of democratic systems.
Evaluate the impact of landmark rulings (Roe, Brown, Obergefell).
Evaluate the concept of Judicial Independence.
Evaluate the elasticity of the 'Necessary and Proper' clause.
Evaluate the impact of the Commerce Clause on state power.
Evaluate the growth of the Executive Branch (Imperial Presidency).
Evaluate the tension between security and liberty.
Construct an argument for the theological basis of human rights.
Synthesize the history of human rights with Christian anthropology.
Construct a biblical definition of Social Justice.
Synthesize the relationship between Justice and Mercy.
Construct a theology of the State.
Synthesize the role of the Christian citizen.
Evaluate modern critical theories of law vs. natural law.
Construct a persuasive argument on a policy issue.
Synthesize the relationship between truth and charity in discourse.
Construct a campaign strategy for a local office.
Synthesize the impact of gerrymandering on representation.
Synthesize the role of the church under persecution.
Construct a comparison of the US and UK governments.
Synthesize the biblical view of representation (Moses/Jethro).
Construct an analysis of a dissenting opinion.
Synthesize the relationship between the Constitution and natural law.
Construct a diagram of the Federal Court system.
Synthesize the role of precedent (Stare Decisis).
Construct a case study of a Constitutional crisis.
Synthesize the dynamic tension between the branches.
Construct an analysis of 'Original Intent' vs. 'Living Constitution'.
Synthesize the influence of Montesquieu on the Founders.
Construct an argument for or against federal mandates.
Synthesize the evolution from Dual Federalism to Cooperative Federalism.
Construct a chart of the specific powers of each branch.
Synthesize the 'Ambition counteracting ambition' concept (Federalist 51).
Construct a legal brief on a landmark Supreme Court case regarding rights.
Synthesize the incorporation of the Bill of Rights to the states (14th Amendment).
Evaluate the effectiveness of checks in the modern era.
Construct a profile of a modern authoritarian regime (e.g., North Korea).
